First question about the "Ice" on rocket, is that "Ice " is a good insulator, "think Igloo" and second question is that there are 3 forms of "Heat transfer" "Conduction, convection and radiation. Not touching each other is No air is No convection and lastly there is only radiation so aluminum foil will be sufficient to insulate the batteries.
Protecting the batteries from the nozzle heat is pretty simple. Paint the sides facing the nozzle white. Paint the sides facing away from the nozzle black. Job done...

35:44 Don't underestimate radiative heating. It's infrared light, needs no air or other means like convective medium to toast you. Remember, a fission bomb miles away will heat up everything long before any hot wind will be under way. Workers at a smelting furnace need special eye protection shading them from IR while they need to look at what they're working at. It's not rocket science :)

With high draw applications, battery packs lose capacity because the voltage drop becomes higher. (higher voltage drop causes the battery to hit its minimum voltage sooner) To use the capacity of the battery efficiently, the pack has to be sized so that the draw is low enough relative to its output capacity. Also i think just meeting such high power demands requires using large packs, otherwise the batteries overheat/lose power/potentially explode

Regarding the radiative heat from the nozzle:
I worked at a lab where they had a kiln which got up to 1500°C so I needed to wear Sunglasses with a >99% extinction coefficient. And when you open the door with your fully extended arm your face gets really hot. Worse then any fever ever.
It also was basically company policy to only keep the door open for about 10s as to not heat the perifery too much.

You could even feel the door was open with your back turned to it and 10m away!

Edit:
Radiated Energy from nozzle (rough estimate)
(Stefan-Bolzmann-Law)
dQ/dt = ε σ A T^4

Assuming:
A=1m²
ε=1 (perfect blackbody)
T=1941K (Ti melting point, what is the nozzle made from?)

We get:
dQ/dt ≈ 790kW of radiated heat!

Thew power density of batteries is limited and draining a pack in 3-4 minutes is about as fast as you can discharge the pack reliably.  The batteries in F1 cars are somewhat faster than that but the amount of power and energy they need to deliver is a fraction of what the batteries in the Electron needs to deliver.  So, it's better to use a smaller number of larger battery packs.  In space the only cooling they have is by radiation.  You would not want to put your hand anywhere near the rocket nozzle when the engine is running, the thermal radiation would burn you real quick.  Many newer ovens use IR heating with light and they are very fast.

@34:30 I think the reason they don't hot swap more often is that smaller batteries may not be able to provide enough power efficiently to the pumps, somewhat similarly to Tesla with a small battery pack will accelerate slower than one with a larger battery pack, despite it being lighter.
If you dump batteries in smaller stages then at any one time there is much less parallel connected batteries and therefore less power can be delivered.

To answer your question Tim, since they are only using the batteries over a period of 5 to 10 minutes, they are power limited rather than energy limited.  The battery size was selected based on available power rather than operating time so discarding discharged batteries as the flight continues would lower the available power.

A launch abort system isn't a requirement, the issue with the shuttle was that there was substantial parts of the flight where single point failure would kill the crew.

What you need is a countermeasure to the failure that is not subject to the same failure mode. This doesn't have to be a launch escape.

I do however think it will be likely that Starship will have ejection seats. These would be useless on the way up but a useful countermeasure to landing failures many of these failures result in total loss of the vehicle and are fast acting and difficult to countermeasure e.g. hard landing fails landing legs, starship topples over and explodes.

To get my retribution in early, reliability is not a safety case, you cannot simply claim that you practice propulsive landing so many times you always get it right. You need to demonstrate that any failure of a mechanical or electrical system is mitigated on a manned system this will be very difficult for something with such fine margins as propulsive landing.

See battery C rating this is a measure of how quickly the battery can discharge (60/C)= discharge time in minutes. There is an inverse relationship between C and battery energy density, ergo high power density batteries are heavier for the same energy. The electron uses 25C batteries to drop them once, the mass penalty between 12C batteries (that would last the whole way) and 25C is minimal, too drop the batteries 2 times would need ~40C, these would have much lower specific energy.

34:10 Also, high-power batteries weigh and cost more per Wh, and you need n+1 times more powerful batteries to have n battery stagings.

To answer your question on batteries, Tim; current draw from a battery cell is limited. Different battery chemistries can be discharged at different rates, but typically the highest achievable continuous rates for the high draw chemistries are about 30 'C'. That means a battery is depleted in 2 minutes (1 hour / 'C' value of 30 = 2 mins). Trying to drive it harder than that will cause a voltage collapse, and damage the battery, possibly causing it to catch fire but definitely reducing the efficiency and not actually drawing any more power because the increase in current is offset by a decrease in voltage.


For example; Rocketlab do something like burn for 5 mins, don't they? (I don't know the specifics.) They could do that with a single battery with a 12C rating, but then they'd be under-utilising the battery cells and carrying more weight for longer than they need to. They could run five batteries for one minute each, but then the C rate would be 60C and the cells voltage would collapse and the batteries would overheat without providing the necessary power. Instead, they use the happy medium; 5 battery packs, run off two of them for two minutes (running them at 30C, which the chemistry can handle and will deplete the cells in 2 mins), then dump the two depleted ones and use the remaining three for the rest of the burn (running those at 20C for the remaining three minutes of burn).


Source - Me, I am an automotive electrical engineer who designs battery systems for cars.

Nozzle vs battery:

In vacuum only black-body radiation comes into effect, which is a fraction compared to heat transfer in athmospheric environments (thermal radiation).
A good portion of that can be reflected with a simple metal foil.

The heat generated by the rapidly discharging batteries is much higher.


Additinally: Given the size of the Electron, that camera is not much farther than the batteries are, and obviously have no foil :)
